Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project, building on the success and best practices of prior ATE projects, advances a grade 9-12 STEM Academy model by creating, implementing, and evaluating a career pathway and course sequence in digital engineering technology & design. The project further scales this blended instructional model for national dissemination and engages minority students historically underrepresented in STEM careers from 30 urban, suburban, and rural Connecticut high schools. The curriculum being developed is embedded with experiential learning to build competency and workforce readiness across all fields of technology supported by the ATE Program. Project activities include: program development and improvement, educator professional development, and curriculum and educational materials development for national dissemination. The project is also conducting a comparative study to examine student STEM interest and engagement and the development of 21st century competencies and skills for successful transition from high school to college in Academy vs. non-Academy project sites.

The project responds to a critical national workforce need - a highly educated and competent technical workforce prepared to compete effectively in the global economy, and has the potential to revitalize the learning environment in 30 Connecticut high schools with diverse student populations, through the creation of a career pathway in digital engineering technology and design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Final Outcomes Related to Project Goals and Objectives

In alignment with the project narrative’s stated goals and objectives, the Academy developed and expanded STEM21 course curricula for grades 9-12, including 3 courses, (E-Commerce Entrepreneurship (2013-14), Digital Engineering (2015), and Wearables, Big Data, & Analytics, 2015-16) that were reviewed and validated by Sage Fox, a Massachusetts-based education research consulting group specializing in increasing STEM career pathway curricula access, with emphasis on underrepresented K-12 populations. Additionally, the curricula model was published and disseminated at national conferences including the NSF ATE and ITest PI & Evaluator Summit conferences in Washington, DC.

All developed courses were sequenced, aligned and made accessible online to schools participating in any of the STEM21 courses. During the funding period, approximately 1,500 participating students from the 12 CT Academy (engaged in full course sequence) public urban, suburban and rural high schools, and 18 additional public schools delivering courses selectively, indicated an increased level of interest in STEM college/career pathways, as determined through delivery of a quality data collection and evaluation plan to assess the satisfactory development and implementation of course materials.

Teachers increased their STEM content and instructional knowledge. The Summer Institute for teacher professional development was updated and refined throughout the program funding period. Ongoing instructional support was provided to teachers, both online and in the classroom through a series of one-on-one teacher coaching sessions with internal program managers, and teacher reflection sessions, well as through mandatory Summer Institute participation for 1st year teachers.  Teacher satisfaction surveys were administered during each Learn21 summer professional development week. 100% of teachers attending the sessions agreed that they were “interesting and worthwhile”. Many teachers continued use of Academy courses beyond project duration.

A continuum of predesignated offsite activities connected the Academy curriculum to college and STEM career pathways. All Academy and STEM21 course students were provided opportunities to participate in a minimum of three experiential meetings in each program school year. Meetings were led by college faculty and/or STEM industry professionals who facilitated activities that fostered the development and presentation of student team projects, and participation of all students and teachers in the annual state-wide Student Innovation Expo, held in CT at the end of each school year.

Identification of project strengths and challenges took place during each year to refine project activities and factors that influenced achievement of STEM content knowledge and interest. Evaluation tools administered to address this goal included a Senior Career Interest Survey, Student Satisfaction Survey, Teacher Satisfaction Survey, Student Expo Survey, Student and Teacher Focus Groups and Interviews, and Fidelity of Implementation Data. The overall findings for students participating in evaluation processes at the end of year 3 demonstrated that approximately 41% of students and minority students agreed or strongly agreed that after engaging in the STEM21 Academy/STEM21course program, their STEM college/career interest had increased. Additionally, surveyed teachers perceived that 57% of students increased interest in STEM careers.
